title: Proposal title
text:
Dataset
A brief description of your dataset including its provenance, dimensions, etc. as well as the reason why you chose this dataset.
Make sure to load the data and use inline code for some of this information.

title: Proposal title
text:
Questions
The two questions you want to answer.

title: Proposal title
text:
Analysis plan

A plan for answering each of the questions including the variables involved, variables to be created (if any), external data to be merged in (if any).

title: About
text:
This project was developed by VIZards For INFO 526 - Data Analysis and Visualization at the University of Arizona, taught by Dr. Greg Chism. The team is comprised of the following team members.

Team member 1: Ashwini R Jannu from MS in Information Science majoring in machine learning (Graduating in 2025).
Team member 2: Lekhashree Honnavalli Jayarama majoring in MS in Data Science (Graduating in 2026).
Team member 3: Mridula Kalaisevan majoring in MS in Data Science (Graduating in 2026).
Team member 4: Hitarth Bharad from MS in Information Science majoring in machine learning (Graduating in 2025).
Team member 5: Hardik Chemburkar majoring in MS in Data Science (Graduating in 2026).
Team member 6: Dhawal Gajwe from MS in Information Science majoring in machine learning (Graduating in 2025).

title: Project title
text:
Math Expressions
You can write LaTeX math expressions inside a pair of dollar signs, e.g. $\alpha+\beta$ renders \(\alpha + \beta\). You can use the display style with double dollar signs:
$$\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i$$
\[
\bar{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nX_i
\]
Limitations:

The source code of a LaTeX math expression must be in one line, unless it is inside a pair of double dollar signs, in which case the starting $$ must appear in the very beginning of a line, followed immediately by a non-space character, and the ending $$ must be at the end of a line, led by a non-space character;
There should not be spaces after the opening $ or before the closing $.

title: Project title
text:
Feeling adventurous?

You are welcomed to use the default styling of the slides. In fact, that's what I expect majority of you will do. You will differentiate yourself with the content of your presentation.
But some of you might want to play around with slide styling. Some solutions for this can be found at https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/revealjs.

title: Tucson Police Data and Analysis
text:
Team Project Contract
Project Title: Tucson Police Data and Analysis
Team Members:

Ashwini R Jannu, ashwinijannu@arizona.edu
Lekhashree Honnavalli Jayarama, lekhashreehj@arizona.edu
Mridula Kalaisevan, lekhashreehj@arizona.edu
Hitarth Bharad, hitarthbharad@arizona.edu
Hardik Chemburkar, hardikchemburkar@arizona.edu
Dhawal Gajwe, dhawalgajwe@arizona.edu

Project Overview

Project Description: This project focuses on analyzing and visualizing crime data reported to the Tucson Police Department from 2018 to the present. The dataset contains over 181,000 incidents, including details such as crime type, location, and date. The primary objective is to gain insights into crime trends over time, geographic distribution of offenses, and other significant patterns. By using data visualization techniques, we aim to present the findings in an engaging and informative way for decision-makers, law enforcement agencies, and the public.
Expected Deliverables:

Dashboard representing crime patterns.
A set of visualizations highlighting crime patterns over time (e.g., monthly/annual trends).



Geographic heat maps showing the distribution of crimes across different wards and divisions in Tucson.
A detailed report summarizing key findings and visualizations.
A final presentation to showcase the visualizations and insights derived from the data.


Team Goals

Project Goals:

Analyze crime trends: Identify patterns in reported crimes across different time periods (year, month, day) and locations (ward, division) in Tucson.



Visualize crime distribution: Create compelling visualizations such as heat maps, bar charts, and line graphs to showcase crime data trends over time and space.
Understand crime categories: Explore the types of crimes (e.g., burglary, homicide, assault) and their frequency to help uncover any significant trends or correlations.
Support decision-making: Provide insights through visualizations that could assist law enforcement, policy makers, and the community in understanding and responding to crime patterns effectively.

Learning Objectives:

Data wrangling: Develop skills in cleaning, transforming, and preparing real-world datasets for analysis.



Data visualization: Learn to design and implement effective visualizations using tools like ggplot2.
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA): Strengthen the ability to extract meaningful insights from large datasets by identifying trends, patterns, and anomalies.
Collaboration and teamwork: Enhance communication and project management skills by working collaboratively within a team structure to deliver a data-driven project.


Team Roles and Responsibilities

Roles (change as needed):



Project Manager: [Ashwini R Jannu] – Ensures timelines are met, organizes meetings, and manages communications.
Data Analyst: [Lekhashree Honnavalli Jayarama, Mridula Kalaisevan] – Responsible for data cleaning, analysis, and exploratory
Visualization Specialist: [Dhawal Gajwe, Hitharth Bharad] – Designs the final visualizations and makes aesthetic choices.
Documentation Lead: [Hardik Chemburkar, Ashwini R Jannu] – Keeps detailed notes, ensures all project decisions are documented, and handles the final report.



Responsibilities:
General Responsibilities: Each team member is responsible for:



Participating actively in all meetings.
Completing their assigned tasks on time.



Communicating openly and promptly if issues arise.

Communication Plan

Meeting Schedule: Weekly on Monday and Wed at 3.15 - 4.15 PM in person.
Primary Communication Platform: Whatsapp.
Decision-Making Process: Decisions will be made by consensus; if a consensus cannot be reached, a vote will be taken.

Work Plan and Timeline

Milestones:

Milestone 1 - Completed
Milestone 2 - In process

Data Collection and Cleaning: Completed by [Date].
Exploratory Data Analysis: Completed by [Date].
Design of Visualizations: Completed by [Date].
Final Presentation and Report: Completed by [Date].
Task Assignments: [Use a table to assign tasks to team members with due dates.]

Accountability and Expectations

Attendance Policy: All team members are expected to attend scheduled meetings unless previously discussed.
Quality of Work: All deliverables should be completed to a professional standard.
Deadlines: All members are responsible for meeting deadlines. If someone cannot meet a deadline, they must notify the team in advance.

Conflict Resolution Plan

Conflict Management: If a conflict arises, team members will:


Discuss the issue openly during a team meeting.
Attempt to resolve the issue through compromise.
If the conflict persists, consult the project supervisor for guidance.

Signatures
By signing below, each team member agrees to the terms of this contract and commits to working together effectively and respectfully.

Ashwini R Jannu (30th Sept 2024)
Lekhashree Honnavalli Jayarama (30th Sept 2024)
Mridula Kalaisevan (30th Sept 2024)
Hitarth Bharad (30th Sept 2024)
Hardik Chemburkar (30th Sept 2024)
Dhawal Gajwe (30th Sept 2024)

This template ensures that everyone understands their roles, responsibilities, and the expectations for the project. It can help prevent misunderstandings and promote effective teamwork throughout the project.
